folder: Union Square & 14th Street (East) & [George Washington Statue.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square East, north from East 14th Street, showing the Henry K. Browne equestrian Washington Statue facing west- ward towards the Park. The latter is on the left and extends to East 17th Street where appears the old Everett House. North of that point, this thoroughfare becomes Fourth Avenue.

View 1: 1859

Brown Brothers

View 2: February 1906

George L. Balgue
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 14th Street (East) - [George Washington Statue.]

folder: Union Square & 4th Avenue & Between 14th and 15th Streets & [George Washington Statue.], Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Union Square: Shows the east side of the Square (4th Avenue), between 14th and 15th Street and the George Washington Statue.
1860

(2) North over 4th Avenue from 14th Street, note, the Everett House to the left of the Statue; it is at 17th Street.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 4th Avenue - Between 14th and 15th Streets - [George Washington Statue.]

folder: Union Square & [14th Street (East) & George Washington Statue.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square: A view northward across the Park from East 14th Street (foreground) and Union Square East (right). Note the Equestrian Washington, the work of Henry K. Browne in the circle. This is now (1937) located in the Park, being moved to its present site about 1930. 1898.

Gift of M. Van Der Weyde.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - [14th Street (East) - George Washington Statue.]

folder: Union Square & Between 14th and 17th Streets (East) & [Union Square Park.], Manhattan, NY
text: Union Square East, north from East 14th to 17th Streets (where it becomes Fourth Ave.), showing the Park on the left and across same a row of buildings on East 17th Street; the latter forming the northern boundary. Materials shown in the foreground are for subway construction. April 5, 1901.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - Between 14th and 17th Streets (East) - [Union Square Park.]

folder: Union Square & 14th Street & [George Washington Statue.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square East, north from but not including 14th Street.
About 1902.
Wurts Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 14th Street - [George Washington Statue.]

folder: Union Square Park & [Union Square & 14th Street (East) & George Washington Statue.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square Park: A northward view from East 14th Street, showing this open area bounded at the left, by Union Square West (Broadway), in the center, by East 17th Street and in the foreground, by Union Square East (Fourth Avenue).

The equestrian Washington monument was removed about 1932 to the Park proper. Close observation will show a political banner on Fourth Avenue bearing the names of Theodore Roosevelt and Charles Fairbanks.

1904

Ewing Galloway
title: Manhattan: Union Square Park - [Union Square - 14th Street (East) - George Washington Statue.]

folder: Union Square & [Union Square Park] & The James Fountain., Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square (Park): The James fountain that stands on the westerly side (Union Square West) at about 15th Street. In the background are the buildings that border the easterly margin, Union Square East, actually a continuation of Fourth Avenue. East 16th Street is behind the figures.

1905

George L. Balgue, photo
title: Manhattan: Union Square - [Union Square Park] - The James Fountain.

folder: Union Square & 14th Street (East) & [Lincoln Statue.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square West, north from East 14th Street, showing the Lincoln statue silhouetted against the buildings that face Union Square. This thoroughfare in reality is a part of Broadway. It’s true identity is lost in that 14th to 17th Street gap that sweeps past the Park. The street cars of the same curved eastward in a serpentine loop forming the well known "Death Curve".

The martyr President stands in the attitude of addressing an audience, and the angularity and ungracefulness of his figure are expressed with painful exactitude. A low curb of granite surrounds the pedestal, and on this are inscribed the famous Gettysburg words, "With malice toward none, With charity for all".

This is the work of Henry K. Browne and was paid for by popular subscription. It was erected in 1868 and complements the nearby equestrian Washington statue.
At the left margin is the 5 story building occupied for years by Tiffany & Company. Opposite is a lower structure with the well known Sol Young, Photographer, as a tenant. These are at East 15th Street. The dominant office building is the 17 story Bank of the Metropolis Bldg., No 31 Union Square West. Broadway reasserts itself in the center background. To the right are buildings that face on the north side of East 17th Street, extending toward Fourth Avenue.

George L. Balgue

February, 1906
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 14th Street (East) - [Lincoln Statue.]

folder: Union Square Park -- Lincoln statue., Manhattan, NY
text:
Union Square (Park): The Lincoln statue being re located in the park. This J.Q.A. Ward work formerly stood at the point where Union Square West and 14th Street joined and past which the Broadway streetcars ran. In the background here is Union Square East (Fourth Ave.) from 15th (right) to 16th (left) Streets.

1929

Berenice Abbott,photo
title: Manhattan: Union Square Park -- Lincoln statue.

folder: Union Square & George Washington Statue., Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Union Square: The Washington Statue in its new location. On the left appear buildings on Union Square East, south from East 15th (left) to 14th Streets. Note the Central Savings Bank (right) at the S.E. corner of Fourth Ave., and 14th Street. About 1930.

(2) Another view at the same time, showing the buildings at East 14th Street and University Place. Union Square West is on the right.

About 1930.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - George Washington Statue.

title: Manhattan: Union Square - [Union Square Park.]

text:
Manhattan
Union Square
Set apart as a "park" in 1811, no doubt Union Square will go down in history for other reasons than Klein's and the fact that it was once the city's fashionable residential section. At the extreme right is the famous Union Square Hotel, erected in 1870 by the Brevoort Estate.

Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Photographs by Berenice Abbott, 50 commerce st., new york city

Title: Union Square, Manhattan  March 20, 1936

Code#1.B.
111 B.I.
